talk.start.para: . - I hope that the clause will pass, because if there is one product that can stand a reduction of bounty it is gold. When the Government announced its intention to pay a bounty on all gold pro- ^duced in excess of the average production for the last three years, the rate of exchange was 9 per cent. Now it is 30 per cent., representing an advantage to the industry of £360,000. A reduction of 50 per cent, will mean an estimated saving of £100,000.
- All that we are asking is that gold shall be placed on the same level as other industries thai are assisted by bounties.

- Bounties are given for the purpose of encouraging the establishment of certain industries. I doubt that the gold bounty is responsible for any increase in the number of prospectors. I am more inclined to believe that the pangs of hunger, due to their inability to secure employment, compels most men to go prospecting for gold. Many men prefer to do that than to remain idle. Also, there is always the prospect of making a lucky find.

.- The State which I have the honour to assist in representing in this chamber is increasing its output of gold very considerably. I do not suggest that this is due entirely to the Government's policy to pay a bounty on production. I think, with the right honorable the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Pearce), that larger numbers of men are being driven by stress of circumstances to go out fossicking. At one time Queensland occupied a prominent place as a gold-producing State, and possibly it will reach its strong position again before long. I have had no protest of any kind from Queensland concerning the Government's proposal to reduce the bounty; but I have had some evidence of a good deal of Western Australian propaganda in Queensland. This impression is strengthened by the remarks of Senator Johnston to-night. It is quite evident that the position has been canvassed from one end of Western Australia to the other. I have good reason to believe that gold producers in Queensland have also been approached. Although, I have had no protest from any gold producer in that State, I have received a letter from one of the leading producers who expresses his views rather tersely. This is what he writes -

quote.para: I see that the Government are cutting the gold bounty in half. I am not surprised at this, and under the circumstances consider that the action is justified.

talk.start.para: - Will that letter be laid on the table, so that we may know by whom it is written ?

- I do not propose to give the writer's name, but if any honorable senator wishes particularly to see it he is at liberty to do so. The writer goes on to say that he had a communication asking for his support to defeat the bill, but he replied that he could not conscientiously do that. I agree with him. Australia is in a very serious position, and we should do our best to assist it by passing these measures. Senator Pearce and other honorable senators mentioned the exchange position. I point out that gold gets the benefit of the exchange position to a greater extent than does any other product.
- At the present time wine is sold without any benefit from the exchange.

- Even wool does not get 30 per cent. Gold gets the maximum benefit of the exchange. The Government's proposal to increase the bounty as the exchange decreases is fair. I understand that when Mr. de Bernales was here, the Western Australian members of this Parliament waited on the Prime Minister, and discussed this matter fully with him, and that they came away from the deputation perfectly satisfied with the result of the interview.
- That is not so.
- I was assured that they were satisfied. Now they come out with this organized objection.
- The honorable senator has been wrongly informed.
- These proposals are reasonable, because the industry will practically be on the same basis as those which suffer a 20 per cent. reduction. I shall support the Government in this matter.

. - When my time expired I was drawing attention to the amounts paid by way of bounties during the last seven years. During that period New South Wales received £2,314,890; Victoria, £456,008; Queensland, in hard cash, £556,438 - which I venture to say is the reason why Senator Thompson is not prepared to accept the principle of equality of sacrifice, seeing that his State has done so well - South Australia, £1,266,893 ; Western Australia, £45,373- less than 1 per cent. of the total amount paid - while Tasmania has been similarly badly treated, the amount paid to that State being only £45,585. The only bounty that could benefit Western Australia, excepting a bounty on wheat - and despite parliamentary approval that has been denied to the State - is to be cut down by 50 per cent. before the first payment becomes due.

speech.para: Senator Thompsonreferred to the deputation that waited on the Prime Minister. He was wrong in saying that the Western Australian members of the deputation were satisfied with the negotiations which took place. We were asked to leave the room while the Prime Minister conferred with Mr. de Bernales and Mr. Scaddan. We were not satisfied, nor were the organizations we represented satisfied. Later we received a reply from the Prime Minister,in which he reluctantly agreed to do something which the PostmasterGeneral had already agreed to do. In fact the announcement of the modification which had been conceded appeared in the Melbourne Age and Argus twelve hours before we left the Prime Minister's room at 5.30 p.m. on the 8th July.

talk.start.para: - My impression is that the deputation was satisfied.
- The following account of a meeting of the Western Australian Gold Bonus Committee might interest honorable senators : -

quote.para: The Western Australian Gold Bonus Committee met at Kalgoorlie municipal chambers on Thursday night,- 9th hist. B. Leslie Taylor of Kalgoorlie presiding. Moved by Mr. Anderton, secretary of Mid- Kalgoorlie Chamber of Mines, seconded1 by Mr. Coa>th, mayor ot Boulder:--

That this meeting of the- Australian. Gold Bonus Committee deplores and protests against what it considers to be a'n unfair attack upon the gold- bonus by the Federal Treasurer;, as such Ls Likely to shake the' confidence of the investing public and destroy all- security, and prevent the introduction of capital into the gold-mining industry which' has been coming forward

speech.para: That was carried by a Majority of nineteen, votes to» three. When, a member of the Labour party moved that the offer of th& Prime Minister be accepted his motion, was rejected by the same majority.

talk.start.para: - Is the honorable senator aware that- gold is now well over £5 an ounce?

- I shall come to- that. I take this opportunity of protesting against the repudiation of an act of Parliament by reducing the gold bounty" by 50 per cent, while other bounties ave to be reduced by only 20 per cent. I object to the discrimination which has been shown against a State, which in the past, has received less than 1 per cent of the amount paid in bounties, a discrimination which has caused a wave of indignation to sweep throughout Western Australia.
- Bo not forget the direct subsidy that Western Australia receives.

- That remark comes with ill grace from an hon.orable senator whose State exploits the Australian, public to the extent of over £7,000,000 a year in connexion, with one of- its basic foods, namely^ sugar. and, in. addition,, has been paid cash, bounties amounting, to £556,438. Surely the repr resentatives of Queensland should be satisfied without trying to prevent me from making out my case.

speech.para: In a leading article headed "Attack on Gold Bonus " the W est Australian stated' -

quote.para: The astonishing, proposal of, the. Federal Government to gift in. ha-lt the gold, board aroused, as well it might, the righteous indignation of the Government, the- Parliament, and1 the people of- Western. Australia. The flimsiest of reasons was assigned by the Federal Treasurer for singling out this particular bounty - the only bounty really from which there was a prospect of benefit; accruing to this State - for special reduction, under the. Commonwealth

Administration's plan for reducing controllable public expenditure. Something might be said for this if other bounty-fed industries were not, indirectly or directly, equally advantaged by the exchange rate. Mr. Theodore- cannot bc blind to the. fact that the wine' industry uin the same- category, where exchange is concerned, as is gold-mining. Nor can he possibly persuade himself that those non-exporting industries,, which- are enjoying- federal subventions, are not substantially benefited by an exchange situation, the effect of which is rigidly to restrict importations of competitive products and consequently to widen greatly their home markets. It is the invidious di*tinction which Mi. Theodore proposes to draw to which exception is so strongly taken and which induced the Legislative- Assembly on

speech.para: Tuesday to carry unanimously Mr. Munsie's motion of emphatic protest.

After dealing with the subject further, the leading article refers to the concession reluctantly given by the Prime Minister many hours after it had been announced by one of his subordinate Ministers. Referring to that very small alteration of the original drastic plan, the West Australian stated -

quote.para: The Government, Parliament and people of the State are not likely to be placated by the announcement that the Federal Treasurer, as the result of representations made to him by the Postmaster-General and member for Kalgoorlie (Mr. A. Green), supported by a deputation of West Australian members and representatives of the mining industry - has agreed that if the rate of exchange decreases, the bounty payable by the Government will increase progressively, so that if the exchange falls back to par the bounty of £1 an ounce will be restored. Such a modification of the original intention of Mr. Theodore's Financial Ein.erge.ncy Bill leaves entirely unaffected theinvidious character of the proposal, which is what is most resented.

talk.start.para: - They do not realize the change that has taken place.

- They object to the discrimination against thegold industry when other industries havebled the Commonwealth of millions of pounds during the" last few years. In reply to a telegram from the presentPostmasterGeneral (M.r-. A. Green), theWestern Australian Chamber of Mines wired -

quote.para: Thanks for telegram. The object of the gold bounty is to accelerate gold- production, and1 provide- additional employment.

speech.para: Protests were made by the Western. Australian Mining Association, the Western Australian Chamberof Manufactures, the, State Executive of the Returned Sailors and Soldiers Imperial League of Australia, the,Fremantle City Council, and, I am pleased to say, also by the Associated Chambers of Manufactures of Australia, whose headquarters are in Melbourne. In contradistinction to the attitude of Senator Thompson, that body wrote to the Prime Minister strongly protesting against a reduction of the gold bounty, which, it was good enough to say, would tell verymuch against the financial rehabilitationof the Commonwealth.

talk.start.para: -The protest was well worked up.
- It was not worked up by me. I have received numerous telegrams on this subject. It is petty for the honorable senator to make such a suggestion.
- Perhaps the pettiness has been displayed by the honorable senator himself.

- There is nothing to justify this invidious discrimination against the gold-mining industry. Senator Thompson was very careful not to disclose the name of the writer of the letter he read, and, consequently, its contents are of little value as compared with the actual facts which I have placed "before the chamber. I have contented myself by quoting the protests of others, including those made in the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia, instead of devoting my time wholly to expressing my own opinion. I agree with every word contained in these protests. The gold-mining industry is capable of doing more in the direction of relieving unemployment rehabilitating the Commonwealth's credit abroad, and of mitigating some of the effects of the prevailing depression throughout Australia than any other Australian industry. I trust that the committeewill agree to deletethis clause, and thus place the gold-mining industry, in the matter of bountieson the same basis as other industries in the eastern States receivingFederal assistance. If we cannot obtain redress here, we cannot get it anywhere. The bounties received by other industries, which are to he. reduced by 2.0 per cent. have been in operation for many years, and have cost thecountry a greatdeal of money, but the gold bounty, which has been in operation for only a few months, is to be reduced by 50 per cent. before any payment whatever has been made under it.

. - Had Senator Johnston not moved to strike out this clause, it was the intention of SenatorRae or myself, who represent the Lang group in this chamber, to move to strike out the word " ten " in paragraph b of sub-clause 2, and to insert in lieu thereof the word " twenty". That portion of theclause would then read"calculated on a basis of twenty shillings Australian currency ". As Senator E.B. Johnston has anticipated my action in this matter, I fee) bound , to support him in the eloquent protest he has made on behalf of the goldmining industry, and, incidentally, the workers of Western Australia, against the reduction of this bounty. It is regrettable that the honorable senator did not take up a similarly strong stand in support of the retention of the existing invalid andold-age pensions which are to be reduced by the present vacillating Scullin Government.

speech.para: SenatorCrawford. - That is not very complimentary.

talk.start.para: -I am not afraid to give hard knocks. I have never beep a squealer. Senator Johnston quoted from the debates in the Legislative Assembly of Western Australia, wherevarious Labour members said that the actof the Scullin Government was one of gross repudiation. When acting as Government Whip, prior to my expulsion from the party because I favoured the policy of the "dinkum" Australian Labour Party, it was my duty to assist Ministers and supporters , of the Government in various directions. I have a vivid recollection of a deputation, headed by Mr. de Bernales, waiting upon the Government La connexion with the gold bounty. The honorable member for Bendigo (Mr. Keane) also pleaded in caucus, and in another place, withthe Scullin Govern- ment-I do not call it the Labour Governmentto paya gold bounty, and thus relieve the unemployed problem in the various States. The instructions of caucus were conveyed to the Government, which eventually decided to introduce a measure providing for the payment of a gold bounty. I have also a vivid recollection of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Pearce) sitting in this chamber until 3 o'clock in the morning to assist in the passage of that measure. I have been under the impression that the policy of repudiation alleged to have been introduced by the Premier of New South Wales (Mr. Lang) was supported only by the honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Beasley), the honorable member for East Sydney (Mr. Ward), the honorable member for Werriwa (Mr. Lazzarini), the honorable member for Martin (Mr. Eldridge), Senator Rae and myself, but during the debate on this measure, honorable senators, including the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Pearce), have been openly supporting proposals involving gross repudiation. I am not very much concerned with the position of the Wiluna Gold Mining Company, which is extending its operations, but I am anxious to assist those workers whom I have been sent here to represent. When in Queensland, in 1911 and 1912, I was a member of the Amalgamated Workers Association, and during that time was engaged in gold and copper mining. In 1913 that organization affiliated with the Australian Workers Union. There are thousands of members of that union in Queensland to-day fossicking for gold. If the gold bounty is retained at the present rate, they will receive considerable benefit. It is amazing to realize that the Minister in charge of this measure is the president of the Australian Workers Union, and that he is receiving the support of the Assistant Minister (Senator Dooley) who is also a leading member of that organization'. If the measure had contained a provision to reduce the concession enjoyed by the sugar industry, Senator Thompson, Senator Reid and Senator Crawford, who have not shown any inclination to support the gold-mining industry, would have been very indignant. According to the Minister for Markets (Mr. Parker Moloney) 250,000 tons Of canned and dried fruits will shortly be shipped from Australia to Canada under the reciprocal trade agreement entered into between Australia and that dominion, which will be of further benefit to those engaged in that industry. This glaring act of repudiation will seriously affect Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland, where many persons are engaged in fossicking for gold. Although the Prime Minister (Mr. Scullin), the Treasurer (Mr. Theodore) supported by some of their stool pigeons have been parading this country denouncing the Lang group, the Government of which they are the principal Ministers, is also repudiating most of its promises and the undertakings previously entered into with different sections of the community. It is difficult to understand how these Ministers can condemn the group of which I am associated for supporting a policy of so-called repudiation when the measures we have passed during the last day or two have consisted solely of acts of repudiation.

. - A measure providing for the payment of a gold bounty was introduced some time ago by this Government. When Senator Daly was Vice-President of the Executive Council, a meeting of those interested in the gold-mining industry was convened, and Mr. de Bernales was appointed chairman of a committee to advise the Government. When this present proposal was made Mr. de Bernales and Mr. Scaddan interviewed members of the Government - I do not know what representations were made - and when I subsequently met these gentlemen they informed me that they were perfectly satisfied with what the Government had agreed to. Seeing that the chairman of the advisory committee which waited upon the Government is satisfied, I propose to support the clause.

. - I intend to support Senator E. B. Johnston, who has moved to delete this clause. I deplore the fact that honorable senators who have spoken so strongly against repudiation are now supporting the principle. If, by defeating any clause, we can lessen the repudiation, my vote. and that of my colleague, will be cast in that way. But, apart from that, I consider that those who speak on behalf of Western Australia have made out a good case. I always believe in doing what measure of justice can be doneto any section of the nation. I contend that, largely owing to circumstances over which it has had no control, Western Australia has not been able to avail herself of the bounties that have been granted to different industries. That reason operated strongly in the minds of honorable senators who are not personally interested in Western Australia, and induced them to vote for the gold bounty. It was realized that, although the other States might be assisted, the largest proportion of Australia's gold production comes from Western Australia, and that, consequently, that State would benefit immediately. Another fact that has to he considered is that gold-mining is largely what might be termed a speculative industry, and that many chance discoveries sometimes prove to be extremely valuable. The stimulus given in this way to those who are seeking for gold may lead to the disclosure of gold-fields of very great value. Even if it enabled hundreds of men in the gold-producing States to obtain a livelihood by fossicking for gold, that, in itself, would be advantageous, and an indirect method of providing work for the unemployed.
- Do the tributers participate in the bounty?
- They do, if they are registered as gold-diggers.

- As nearly all of the States produce gold to a greater or less extent, and may produce more under this stimulus, and as no good reason has been advanced for the reduction of the bounty by 50 per cent., compared with a reduction of 20 per cent. in the case of other industries, on the ground of justice alone, I must support Senator Johnston.

. - I wish to say a few words concerning this matter, in which I have taken a very deep interest, and about which I have spoken at length in this chamber. In my consideration of the subject, I recognize neither Western Australia nor any other State. During the last two or three years my concern has been solely for the solvency of my country.

speech.para: I do not concede that any of the actions which arc being taken under this measure constitute repudiation. It is a salvage measure, designed to save something, at least, of what we now have. These proposals cannot be criticized from that angle. It is infinitely better for this suffering to be inflicted to-day than that something more drastic should be imposed in the immediate future. Applying those principles to the gold bounty, it may be said that I should not support my friend Senator Johnston, but that I should take the stand that the gold-mining industry must suffer in common with other industries. But I have not heard the Minister, or anybody else, explain where this matter intruded itself in the deliberations of the Premiers Conference. I have been under the painful necessity of reading the whole of the debates that took place when the Prime Minister met the Premiers in Melbourne, and I have not been able to find any mention of a proposal to interfere with the gold bounty. Yet, to our surprise, an announcement was made in the press that the bounty was to be reduced by 50 per cent. If the Minister claims that this is an essential part of the plan, and can prove his case, I shall be constrained, much against my wish, to vote with the Government.

talk.start.para: - It is a most essential part of the plan.
- Not a word was said at the conference about interfering with these bounties. The gold bounty is the basis of our future solvency.
- Did it not follow that these things had to be taken into consideration ?

-This is neither the time nor the place to take them into consideration. The time of reckoning will come, and we shall have to take other action in regard to these bounties. I am astonished that this measure should deal with such trivial matters as cotton, flax, linseed and sundry other things, when there are one or two outstanding matters which this Parliament must take into consideration if it is to rehabilitate this country. I should not, at this late hour, refer to what the late Senator Givens, ex-President of the Senate once described as the sectarian question - sugar; but it is obvious that such questions must emerge. The first raid is made on gold, forsooth for the purpose of relieving the Commonwealth Treasury, against what? Against an increase in the production of gold, upon which the future of this country depends, and without which we cannot carry on? During the last twelve months, how has this Government remained in office? How has it been able to avoid facing up to the position with which it is now confronted? Simply by the export of gold to England. Those exports, prior to the last shipment, totalled £32,000.000. The importance of the gold industry to this country cannot be measured; it goes to the very root of our national existence. That is evidenced by the adoption by the Macmillan Commission of the report of the Gold Delegation of the League of Nations. It is the basis of the whole of the credit of this country. I admit that I was impressed by the statement of Senator Millen, that Mr. de Bernales and Mr. Scaddan had accepted the measure of relief given under the bill.
- Because they could get no more.

- There was this realization, that they are in as good a position as they were before; because, when the Gold Bounty Act was passed, the rate of exchange was in the region of 9 per cent. or 9½ per cent., while to-day it is up to 30 per cent., and the bill provides for the restoration of the bounty as the rate of exchange drops. Until I heard that Senator Johnston was moving in the matter to-day, I believed that that was a compromise which had been accepted by those who have at heart the best interests of the gold-mining industry in Western Australia. But to my amazement, the honorable senator stated that that was not so, and that the powers that be in Western Australia were up in arms against the proposal of the Government. I want honorable senators to understand that any support which I may give Senator Johnston will be actuated not by State interests, but by something that goes far deeper. I should like the Minister to state whether this compromise was arranged by Mr. de Bernales, who is chairman of the Gold Committee. I understand that that committee is not yet a legal body, but that it has some sort of floating existence, so that it may protect and stimulate the gold-mining industry. This action is likely to have a serious repercussion. I should prefer some other bounties to be wiped out before the gold bounty was interfered with in any way, because delicate negotiations in regard to this matter have already taken place, the result of which may be greatly to relieve the difficult position in which this country finds itself.
- The price of gold is as high as it ever was. The industry is not suffering on that account.

- Governments cannot afford to chop and change, particularly with big financial interests. When the Gold Bounty Act, whichI assisted the Government to pass, was enacted a few months ago, that action was represented as evidence of the goodwill of the Government of Australia towards the gold-mining industry, and efforts were made to secure a large amount of capital for the development of low-grade propositions in Western Australia, and for other action that would place the industry on a really sound footing. Considerable sums of money were promised overseas for that purpose, on the faith of what the Government had done. I have read cables which show how shocked are the authorities and the financial people on the other side of the world who were prepared to gamble their money on the strength of the inducement that was offered. This will not prove helpful to Australia overseas, where she so greatly needs help.
- It will not affect the issue.

- It will affect the issue to a far greater extent than my friend realizes. Had we put our house in order, it would not have been necessary to ship any gold to England. I point out to the Assistant Minister (Senator Dooley) that although the price of gold is satisfactory, and the exchange is beneficial, this interference with a contract which it was thought would operate for ten years will strike at the root of the Government's financial solvency. I should like to hear what explanation the Minister has to offer, because my mind is in a state of flux. I came here prepared to support the measure, believing that the gold-mining industry was absolutely satisfied with this proposal as a compromise, and that no difficulty would be experienced in putting matters right in the old world. I feel that we are traversing a very dangerous path. I do not mind admitting that when I was spoken to regarding the matter I said that if it were absolutely essential to Australia's financial safety, and necessary to the plan of financial rehabilitation, the industry would perhaps have to accept the proposed reduction, and that probably the only relief likely was that which is proposed by the bill, for the alteration of the bounty so as to conform to any rise or fall in the cost of exchange.

. - I can substantiate the statement made by Senator Millen that Messrs. Scaddan and de Bernales, who were in consultation with the Prime Minister on this matter, expressed their delight at the agreement arrived at. Provision is made in the bill for any variation in. the rate of exchange to be reflected in the rate of the bounty on gold. If the rate of exchange becomes normal the full bounty of £1 an oz. will be restored. Senator Johnston has complained that Western Australia hasnot received as much assistance from the Commonwealth as other States have been given. He forgets that during the last six years Western Australia has received grants amounting to approximately £2,000,000, a form of assistance which has not been granted to several of the other States. Although the matter was not dealt with specifically at the Premiers Conference the representatives of the Commonwealth gave an undertaking that in miscellaneous ways they would effect a saving of another £1,000,000, and this is one of the means by which they are endeavouring to carry out that promise.
- Then why is this clause not under the part of the bill headed, " Miscellaneous " ? Why tell lies about the matter?

- There is no lie about it. Senator McLachlan said that he did not know that the Premiers Conference dealt with the matter. As a matter of fact, it did not, but the Commonwealth's representatives agreed to save another £1,000,000 under the heading of " Miscellaneous " and this is one of the means the Government has adopted to carry out its promise. Honorable senators are aware of the circumstances in which the Government finds itself. It is at its wit's end to right matters and it thinks that a reduction of the gold bounty will help it to do so.
- Can the Minister say what the saving will amount to?
- No one can tell that until the returns are sent in at the end of the year. I hope that the committee will agree to the clause as printed.

Where any payment, the reduction of which is authorized by any section contained in Part II. or III. of this Act, is not of a periodical nature, (not being a payment the reduction of which is authorized to bemade from such date as the Minister directs ) , and is made after the date fixed for the commencement of that section, it shall be subject to reduction in accordance with that section.
That after the word "shall", sub-clause (2), the words " insofar as it relates to services performed on or after that date " be inserted.
Clause also verbally amended, and, as amended, agreed to.
First schedule consequentially amended, and, as amended, agreed to.
